title: Feminine Plurals (-a/-i -> -es)
reading_greek:
GROUP 1: -A NOUNS
Η γυναίκα -> Οι γυναίκες (The woman -> The women)
Η ώρα -> Οι ώρες (The hour -> The hours)
Η μέρα -> Οι μέρες (The day -> The days)
Η ζώνη -> Οι ζώνες (The belt -> The belts)
Η πίτσα -> Οι πίτσες (The pizza -> The pizzas)

GROUP 2: -H NOUNS
Η τιμή  -> Οι τιμές (The price -> The prices)
Η φωνή  -> Οι φωνές (The voice -> The voices)
Η φίλη -> Οι φίλες (The girlfriend -> The girlfriends)
Η πόλη -> Οι πόλεις (The city -> The cities)

ACCUSATIVE PLURAL (The Object)
- Βλέπω τις γυναίκες. (I see the women.)
- Ακούω τις φωνές. (I hear the voices.)
- Περιμένω τις φίλες μου. (I am waiting for my friends.)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: FEMININE PLURALS [(See Page 44)](/assets/grammar.pdf#page=44)

1. THE 'GOLDEN RULE': Feminine nouns are easy in plural. 
   - Almost ALL of them end in -es.

2. ARTICLE CHANGES:
   - Nominative: 'H' becomes 'Oi'. (H ora -> Oi ores).
   - Accusative: 'Tin' becomes 'Tis'. (Tin ora -> Tis ores).

3. PRONUNCIATION:
   - 'Oi' (Nom) and 'H' (Sing) sound identical (ee).
   - 'Tis' (Acc) is distinct. You can hear the 's'.
audio_script:
Feminine Plurals are the easiest in Greek. 

Whether the word ends in Alpha (H gynaika) or Eta (H timi), the plural ending is always '-es'.
- Oi gynaikes.
- Oi times.

The Article changes too:
- 'H' becomes 'Oi' (Subject).
- 'Tin' becomes 'Tis' (Object).

Pay attention to the Accusative 'Tis'. 
'Tis' is clearly feminine plural. 
If you say 'Tous' (Masc), people expect men. 
If you say 'Tis' (Fem), people expect women or feminine things. 
'Vlepo TIS files mou' (I see my girlfriends).
